text.section: The Joint Ethics Committee shall adopt written procedures for conducting a hearing to consider a complaint, allegation summary, and written answer, if any, as provided in § 15-518(b) of this subtitle.

section.section: If the Joint Ethics Committee determines that a hearing is required under § 15-518(b) of this subtitle, the Joint Ethics Committee, by a two-thirds vote of the members of the Joint Ethics Committee, may issue one or more subpoenas that require the appearance of a person, the production of relevant records, and the giving of relevant testimony.

If the Joint Ethics Committee exercises subpoena powers under this paragraph, the legislator who is the subject of the investigation may require the Joint Ethics Committee to issue one or more subpoenas on that legislator's behalf.
A request to appear, appearance, or submission of evidence does not limit the subpoena power of the Joint Ethics Committee.

A subpoena issued under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be served:
in the manner provided by law for service of a subpoena in a civil action;
before the time that the subpoena sets for appearance or production of records; and
with the following documents:
A person who is subpoenaed to appear at a hearing is entitled to receive the fees and allowances that are provided for a person who is subpoenaed by a circuit court.

A person may be held in contempt if the person unjustifiably:
fails or refuses to comply with a subpoena for appearance;
appears but fails or refuses to testify under oath; or
unless the directive is overruled by a majority vote of the members of the Joint Ethics Committee who are present at the hearing, disobeys a directive of the presiding chairman at the hearing to answer a relevant question or to produce a record, including electronic record that has been subpoenaed.
By a two-thirds vote of all of the members of the Joint Ethics Committee, the Joint Ethics Committee may apply for a contempt citation to a circuit court.
